titleproper.value: Guide to the Jennifer Stafford Papers <num>WAG.001</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Finding aid prepared by Tamiment Staff

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-05-09T20:15:00</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

abstract.value: Jennifer Stafford was an Elevator, Ride and Tramway Engineer for the State of California. This collection focuses on the role of women in the International Union of Elevator Constructors and their struggle for recognition within the union. It contains legal papers from Adrian v. Dover, the first case dealing with sexual harassment brought by a group of Elevator Workers, a letter written by Stafford to city supervisors expressing concern that no women were being hired by elevator contractors, a report by Jennifer Stafford to the Human Rights Commission stating that elevator contractors were not fulfilling their minority goals on city jobs, papers from the Equal Rights Advocates, union membership cards, contracts and photographs.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Jennifer Stafford Papers; WAG 001; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Jennifer Stafford, 2002. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 2002.002, 2002.004, and NPA 2005.250.
Jennifer Stafford was an Elevator, Ride and Tramway Engineer for the Division of Occupational Safety and Health of the State of California.

This collection focuses on the role of women in the International Union of Elevator Constructors and their struggle for recognition within the union. It contains legal papers from Adrian v. Dover, the first case dealing with sexual harassment brought by a group of Elevator Workers, a letter written by Stafford to city supervisors expressing concern that no women were being hired by elevator contractors, a report by Jennifer Stafford to the Human Rights Commission stating that elevator contractors were not fulfilling their minority goals on city jobs, papers from the Equal Rights Advocates, union membership cards, contracts and photographs.

subject.value: Women in the labor movement |z United States.
Sex discrimination against women -- United States.
Building trades -- Employees -- Labor unions -- United States.

corpname.value: United States. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission
